What is this?

This sculpture represents a woman lying on her tomb, as though she were sleeping peacefully.
She was with her husband in a chapel in the church of the Augustinian Convent of Toulouse.
Although she is lying down, the folds in her clothes indicate that she is represented as though she were standing.

Details from an illumination representing a tombstone cutter, in Estoire del Saint Graal, La Queste del Saint Graal, Morte Artu, circa 1315–1325, France Parchment codex © London British Library MS Royal 14 E III f. 66v

Tomb of Aiol ‘de Foro’ and his wife Asceline, 12th century, at Ardenne Abbey, in Jean Adhémar with Gertrude Dordor, Les tombeaux de la collection Gaignières, in Gazette des Beaux-Arts, July–September 1974, p. 34, illus. 143
Plan of the Augustinian Convent of Toulouse (detail), photographic reproduction by E. Delon of an etching from 1653 by I. Seguenot. © Mairie de Toulouse, Archives municipales, Cote 26Fi84
What does Joan’s face tell us?

Thanks to documents found in the archives, we know that this is Joan, a woman who lived at the beginning of the fourteenth century. She was married to John of Mantes, the king’s master builder. He was responsible for the king’s buildings in Toulouse and the surrounding region. The couple owned a large estate in nearby Launaguet.
John of Mante’s will, (22 November 1316), parchment Haute-Garonne Record Office © Photo: Conseil départemental de la Haute-Garonne/Archives départementales/1 E 458.

Map of France showing Paris, Toulouse and Mantes (now Mantes-la-Jolie). 
© Graphics: Teddy Bélier
What does Joan’s face tell us?

Joan is represented as an upper-class woman from the north of France. However, the fact that her eyes are closed, rather than open as they would be in the North, shows that she wished to follow the mores of the South. This indicates that she was originally from the south of France.

Recumbent effigy and face detail of Algayette of Rodez, wife to Amauri of Narbonne. Ancient cathedral of Narbonne 
© Service culturel de la ville de Narbonne

Head of the recumbent effigy of Joan of Toulouse, from Gercy Abbey in Varennes-Jarcy (Essonne), circa 1285. Paris, Musée de Cluny – National museum of the Middle Ages. Photo © RMN-Grand Palais (musée de Cluny – musée national du Moyen-Âge) / Gérard Blot
Tomb of Margaret of Artois (detail of the face), 14th century, marble, from the Jacobin Convent, Paris. © Basilique Saint-Denis. Photo: Pascal Lemaître / Centre des monuments nationaux
What do her clothes tell us?

Her fashionable clothing shows that she was rich, as she was the wife of an important servant of the king here in Toulouse. Note that Joan wears no jewellery, as it would not have been considered appropriate in a religious context.
The style of the clothes and the drapery date the effigy to the beginning of the fourteenth century.

View of the captioned clothes :
– Wimple: a piece of white material which frames the face and covers the neck. 
– Shift: undergarment worn day and night, next to the skin.
– Kirtle: worn over the shift, like a dress.
– Surcoat: with or without sleeves, worn over the kirtle.

Isidore de Séville (saint ; 0560?-0636), Etymologies et Sentences d'Isidore de Séville, 1250-1299, manuscrit enluminé, Bibliothèque municipale de Toulouse, Ms. 176. Folio 126 (dtéail). Photo Gaston Boussières
Visuel à construire avec la reconstituion de la Gisante avec légendes ci-dessus
What is the accessory she is carrying over her arm?

Eugène Viollet-le-Duc included this accessory in his dictionary of architecture under the name aumônière, in other words a small purse containing coins that the rich would give to the poor. However, in this instance it is a small book bag – or 'girdle book' – which contained a prayer book. It informs us of Joan's privileged status. Books were still rare and expensive in this period.

Drawing of Joan of Mantes' book bag by Eugène Viollet-le-Duc, in E. Viollet-le-Duc, Dictionnaire raisonné du mobilier français, vol. III, part 7: clothes, jewellery, toilet articles, book of Hours, p. 450. Photo: Daniel Martin.
Codex Manesse, Cod. Pal. Germ. 848, fol. 64r, Germany, Heidelberg University library © Rights reserved A codex is a notebook made up of handwritten pages bound together as a book.

Attributed to Jean Pucelle, Hours for use in Amiens (Lescalopier 016, f. Annunciation), Amiens Municipal Library © Ville d'Amiens. The rule included in the picture shows how small the book is. Just 5.4 cm!
What are the marks on the cushion at Joan's head?
We can clearly see hand-prints, marks supposedly left by an angel who had been supporting the cushion. This was a common feature of the tombs of wealthy men and women in the period.

Cast of the Tomb of Louis and Philip of Alençon, with restoration from the 19th century. Basilica of Saint-Denis. © Photo: Charlotte Riou Louis and Philip were the grandsons of Saint Louis. The original comes from Royaumont Abbey and now lies, unrestored, in the Cluny Museum, Paris. Late 13th century.
Tomb of Philip of France (1222–1234), called Philip Dagobert, from Notre-Dame de Royaumont Abbey (Asnières-sur-Oise). Basilica of Saint-Denis. © Photo: Charlotte Riou
What was at Joan's feet?

We can distinguish a rounded shape beneath her feet. It was undoubtedly a dog, a symbol of loyalty in most female recumbent effigies. Men were accompanied by other animals, such as a lion, a monster, a panther or a bear.
Recumbent effigy of Guillaume Durant the Younger, detail of a demonic monster at his feet. © Toulouse, musée des Augustins. Photo: Daniel Martin

Recumbent effigy of Blanche of France, detail of dogs at the base, early 14th century. From the Cordeliers of Paris (Franciscan Order). Basilica of Saint-Denis. © Photo: Charlotte Riou Daughter to Saint Louis and Margaret of Provence.

Recumbent effigy of Margaret of Artois, detail. Early 14th century. From the church of the Jacobin Convent of Paris. Basilica of Saint-Denis. © Pascal Lemaître / Dist. Centre des monuments nationaux The two dogs represent the spouses’ tenderness.

John of Liège, Recumbent effigy of Charles IV, called the Fair (reigned 1322–1328), detail of the lion and the lioness at his feet. From Maubuisson Abbey circa 1370. © Paris, BouMusée du Louvre, Dist. RMN-Grand Palais / Thierry Ollivier

John of Cambrai, Recumbent effigy of John of Berry, detail of the bear at his feet. Early 15th century. From the Sainte-Chapelle of Bourges, now Bourges Cathedral. © Photo Patrick Müller / Centre des monuments nationaux According to M. Pastoureau, the bear would have been chosen as an emblem because of the similarity between the English word 'bear' and the name of the province: Berry.
In colour or black and white?

In the fourteenth century expensive materials, such as marble, alabaster and ivory, were left unembellished to show off their whiteness. Some gilding or touches of red and/or blue were added to better highlight the white. Joan’s recumbent effigy bears no trace of colour. It was perhaps never painted.
